ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ACCIDENTS ALONG EAST COAST PARKWAY
(Preventive measures)



    1. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Home Affairs what measures can be taken to prevent the further occurrence of accidents such as that which occurred on the East Coast Parkway when a prime mover ran into a stationary car and caused the death of Mdm Cassandra Khor.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, the accident involving Mdm Khor was very unfortunate. The Traffic Police and the Land Transport Authority already have plans in the coming months to facilitate the early towing away of breakdown vehicles on expressways, as well as to control the speed of heavy vehicles.

    The LTA introduced an Expressway Monitoring and Advisory System (EMAS) for the Central Expressway (CTE) on 1st March 1998. EMAS spots accidents and breakdown vehicles which are then removed by LTA's towing contractor. The quick removal of obstruction ensures that

Column: 1427

the source of danger is removed as soon as possible and also minimises delays to other motorists. EMAS will eventually be extended to the other expressways, like the BKE, PIE and ECP.

    The Traffic Police is also working with LTA and transport associations such as the Motor Traders Association and the Freight Forwarders Association to look into requiring heavy vehicles to install speed limiters. These limiters would restrict the speed at which heavy vehicles can travel. Once the vehicle reaches a certain pre-determined maximum speed, the petrol-supply to the engine would be regulated, and the vehicle would not be able to travel beyond that speed. Such limiters are already in place in almost all SBS and TIBS buses. The first phase of implementation is expected to start in July this year.

    Besides taking preventive measures, the Traffic Police will also step up its enforcement against heavy vehicles. The Traffic Police has been charging drivers of heavy vehicles involved in serious and fatal accidents and, on a selective basis, slight injury accidents. Henceforth, the Traffic Police will charge all drivers of heavy vehicles who are involved in accidents in court. The Traffic Police will also charge drivers of heavy vehicles who are caught speeding. Errant drivers will be liable for heavier penalties as well as disqualification from driving. For careless driving, a first offender will be liable to a fine of $1,000 or 3 months imprisonment. For dangerous driving, the offender will be liable to a fine of up to $3,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both. The offender can also be liable to disqualification from driving. In suitable cases, the Traffic Police will press for a deterrent sentence, including imprisonment sentences and disqualification from driving.

    Sir, the Traffic Police takes a serious view of motorists who blatantly flout traffic regulations, such as driving on expressway shoulders. Expressway shoulders are meant only for vehicles to

Column: 1428

stop temporarily during emergencies, for example, when a vehicle breaks down. Motorists should not treat a road shoulder as an additional carriageway. Anyone who drives on the expressway shoulder can be fined up to $1,000 or 3 months imprisonment. The offender will also be given 4 demerit points. A repeat offender can be fined up to $2,000 or jailed up to 6 months.

    Sir, the Traffic Police is currently reviewing the demerit points system. The review will include all offences that currently attract demerit points, such as driving along expressway shoulders.

    The Traffic Police would also like to advise motorist whose vehicle has broken down along the expressway to switch on the hazard lights and display the vehicle breakdown sign. The motorist and his passengers should move away from the breakdown vehicle and stand behind the guard rail. They should face the direction of the on-coming traffic and not venture onto the carriageway at all times.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, when can we expect the full implementation of the speed limiters for heavy vehicles? Also, what sort of heavier penalties could we expect for drivers who violate these laws? For example, would they have more demerit points than before?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the implementation of the speed limiters will be carried out in phases. The first phase will begin with new heavy vehicles which are registered from 1st July onwards. Thereafter, existing heavy vehicles will be installed with speed limiters in phases over a period of time, and we hope they can do it as soon as possible, because it is actually a very simple device costing just a few hundred dollars to install.

    As for the demerit points and the fines, the whole demerit point system is being reviewed, whether it is just parking at demerit point zones, speeding or any other offence that would attract demerit points. I think far too many people are beating red lights and speeding. These

Column: 1429

constitute about 70% of the total traffic offences. I think motorists should be advised not to violate any of the traffic regulations because the Traffic Police is earnest and serious in addressing this problem, and they will up the demerit points quite severely.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Since the Minister mentioned that there will be a review of the demerit points system, in the spirit of S21, would the Minister then guarantee that there would be full consultation before he implements such a demerit points system?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I think the public is already quite unhappy that we have so many motorists who violate the law, and that they want the Police to take tough action against them. An example is this question of illegal parking. Readers of newspapers would have noted that the newspapers ran a series of articles carrying views from residents, motorists and other people who complained about illegal parking and they want the Police to do more in dealing with this problem. As a result and in response to this - the Traffic Police has also been considering this - the Police has therefore demarcated a number of areas to attract demerit points if motorists park in these areas. And the number of such zones which will attract demerit points for illegal parking will increase to quite a significant number. I can assure Members here that the Police will go all out to deal with this problem.

Column: 1429

PARTICIPATION IN SPORTS AMONG FEMALE POPULATION


    2. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for Community Development what measures are being taken or being contemplated to promote participation in sports among the female population, especially at the community and recreational level.

    The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Sir, participation of women in sports and physical fitness activities has grown considerably since the launch of the

Column: 1430

Sports For Life Programme by the Prime Minister in 1996.

    Under the Sports For Life Programme, the Singapore Sports Council administers fitness tests and organises the Learn-to-Play programme. Between September 1996 and December 1996, a 4-month period, 763 women participated in the Sports For Life Fitness Assessments. For the whole of 1997, the number jumped to 15,968 and more than doubled to 42,674 in 1998. Women make up 55%, indeed a majority, of fitness test participants. Women's participation in the Learn-to-Play Schemes has also increased, from 19,237 in 1996 to 27,735 and 40,145 in 1997 and 1998 respectively.

    At the community level, women are encouraged to use the ClubFITT gymnasium facilities available at the Regional Sports and Fitness Centres. In 1998, there were 143,922 female users. This is up from 9,635 in 1996 and 88,200 female users in 1997.

    At the national level, the Singapore Sports Council, together with the People's Association Women's Executive Committee Co-ordinating Council, the Ministry of Health, the NTUC Women's Programme Committee and the Singapore Council of Women's Organisations (SCWO) will be organising the third National Sports Carnival for Women on 6th June 1999. We anticipate that this event will attract 13,000 women participants.

    To further emphasise the promotion of women in sports, the first Women and Sports Conference was held in Singapore in March this year, during which Singapore endorsed the objectives and principles of the Brighton Declaration to increase the participation of women and girls in sports in Singapore. As a follow-up to the Conference, a working group is being established to draw up an action plan to promote the greater participation of women in sports.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, besides providing venues, would the Minister devote more resources towards

Column: 1431

developing and promoting regular participation in sports that are popular such as netball, but which are not necessarily designated as core sports?

    Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, the Member may be pleased to know that the Sports Council indeed supports the activities of the Netball Association of Singapore. As Members know, the Netball Association has courts at Kallang and it will be developing a family centre which is close to the courts. That centre is partly funded by the Singapore Sports Council. We will definitely give all the support that we can to the Netball Association of Singapore and to netball as a sport. If I am not mistaken, it is one of the largest women's sports in Singapore, and we are also encouraging it in schools.

Column: 1431

SALE OF LAND


    3. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Minister for National Development when will the Government launch the next sale of land.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the budget debate in March this year, I informed the House that the Government will announce in September 1999 the land sales for next year. There is no change in our schedule.

    Although demand in the private residential sector has picked up in the last quarter of 1998 and the first quarter of 1999, there is still ample supply of new private housing units. As at first quarter of 1999, there were 4,100 launched but unsold units. Another 9,800 units had the pre-requisite approvals to be launched for sale. In addition, there were 6,300 units from other land sales projects and 3,700 units from private land projects under construction which did not have approval for sale yet. This adds up to 24,000 unsold units in the pipeline available for future sales. A resumption of land sales for residential units in year 2000 would ensure that this pipeline is maintained.

    As for land sales for commercial development, the Government has announced

Column: 1432

in June last year that it would release a site at Clarke Quay this year. There is also sufficient supply of commercial space. The supply of office and shop space under construction was 790,900 sq metres and 150,300 sq metres respectively as at first quarter 1999. These would be sufficient to meet demand for the next few years. We would review the situation and announce our plans for future land sales for commercial developments in September as well.

NEW HDB FLATS
(Size)



    4. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for National Development why new 4- and 5-room Housing and Development Board flats are discernibly smaller than older models of 4- and 5-room flats respectively, especially since the general expectation will be of better and more spacious housing when average incomes increase.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the aspirations of young families to have better and more spacious housing would have to be balanced with the limited land resource of our small country.

    Compared with the 1970s and the 1980s, we now have smaller family units. We would not be optimising land use if we had continued building new flats of the same size as the older models without taking into consideration the family size of today. However, this does not mean that those living in new flats today are worse off. The living space per person has increased through the years due to the reduced household size.

    What we can do to meet the higher expectations of today's young families is to build flats with better quality, finishes and design. HDB has also been building more Design-and-Build, and Design-Plus flats. The designs of such flats are comparable with private condominiums. HDB will continue to review the design and finishes of new HDB flats to meet the preferences and needs of the majority of flat applicants.

Column: 1433



    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, is it not possible to give potential applicants a choice; in other words, to have 4-room flats of various sizes, because a certain family size of, say, parents plus two children, may only need a 4-room flat, but they may prefer a bigger 4-room flat rather than the present size of smaller 4-room flats.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The 4-room flats come in a wide variety of sizes, from the smaller ones, 85 sq metres to 90 sq metres, to above 90 sq metres. If they want bigger 4-room flats, they can buy from the resale market, and with the aid of the CPF housing grant, they can go for the bigger 4-room flats of 100 sq metres and above. So there is enough variety in terms of sizes.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: But will the Minister not agree that this is precisely the point? In other words, there are some families that are dropping out of the new queue in order to buy resale flats of the same type, for example, 4-room flats, precisely because they are bigger.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: It shows that the policy is working. We give them the choice. They exercise their choice. We are not unhappy about it. They are happy; we are happy.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: But I think here the preference could be that they actually want a new flat, but because of the size, they would have to go for a resale flat.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If they want a new flat, then they have to settle for the small flats.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, may I ask what is the Ministry's policy towards current HDB owners of budget flats, like 4- and 5-room flats, who wish to downgrade to smaller flats, like 3-room flats, due to the fact that they cannot afford payments for the larger flats because of the economic downturn?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If they want to downgrade, they can sell off their 4-room or 5-room flats and buy 3-room flats in the

Column: 1434

resale market, as long as they have satisfied the 5-year occupation rule.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: Is there any chance for a review of the policy on the 5-year rule? Because some of the newer flat owners who have just taken possession of their 4-room flats find that it is rather difficult to keep up with their payments due to the economic downturn.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: We will look at each case on its own merits. If indeed, they are under financial stress and they cannot continue with their payments, we will, of course, facilitate their downgrading to a 3-room flat, notwithstanding their not meeting the 5-year occupation rule.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, while agreeing with the Minister that the families are getting smaller, there may be some families, because of affluence, that want to have bigger flats. Would the Minister consider the plight of those families?

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If they are richer, I see no plight.

Column: 1434

POLICY ON PROSTITUTION



    5. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will state what is the policy of his Ministry towards prostitution.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, prostitution per se is not an offence under our laws. This has been so since the colonial days. Singapore is not the only country where prostitution is not an offence. Many other countries also adopt the same position.

    Governments around the world and through the ages have tried to eradicate prostitution, but none had succeeded. Criminalising prostitution will only drive such activities underground, resulting in crime syndicates taking control over such activities.

    The Ministry of Home Affairs therefore has taken a pragmatic approach of recognising that the problem cannot be totally suppressed or wished away. Our

Column: 1435

approach is therefore to contain the situation, particularly through continuing enforcement against prostitutes and pimps who solicit in public. Soliciting and pimping in public are offences under the Miscellaneous Offences (Public Order and Nuisance) Act and the Women's Charter respectively. The Police also conduct regular checks at known locations and on those involved in the trade to prevent criminal gangs from exploiting the prostitutes, and underaged girls from getting involved.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the strict offences created under Part X of the Women's Charter for the suppression of prostitution and living on immoral earnings are strictly enforced or not?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: If Police receive complaint that somebody is living on the immoral earnings of somebody, then, of course, they will take action.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister tell us what checks are made to see that hotels do not allow any prostitution in their premises?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, we have maybe close to 30,000 hotel rooms in Singapore and definitely nobody expects the Police to go round checking all the hotels to ensure that they do not engage in prostitution. But when there are complaints against somebody operating a brothel in a hotel, then, of course, Police will go and take action.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Are we to understand that this pragmatic view that the Minister says his Ministry has adopted is that this is something that we cannot do anything about? So is the Ministry considering amending the laws in the Women's Charter?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: What the Ministry has done is to ensure that crime syndicates, gangsters and secret societies do not get involved in controlling this trade.

Column: 1436

And if they do, then Police will take action. We all know that no country has ever succeeded in eradicating prostitution and therefore we have taken a pragmatic approach in ensuring that only certain areas have such activities taking place. And it is better that the Police know where these areas are and enforcement action can be taken, rather than to disperse these brothels to the whole of Singapore and we have a cat-and-mouse game chasing after them or, worse still, drive them underground, and they will be operating everywhere.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Perhaps the Minister did not understand the import of my question. If it is felt that you cannot control it, then is the Ministry considering legalising prostitution and containing it to just one or two areas in Singapore and keeping a strict watch on the premises which indulge in this?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, there is no need to legalise it but we can at the same time deal with the problem in a pragmatic way.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister realise that if you have laws and they are not enforced by the enforcement agencies, it only leads to disrespect for the law?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the relevant section in the Women's Charter is still being enforced. If there are underaged girls being involved in prostitution, if there are people coercing women or girls into prostitution, they will face the force of the law.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: Would the Minister consider moving brothel houses from the city centre - I am speaking of Little India - to somewhere else?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: I am not sure I heard clearly his point about moving what houses from Little India.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: We all know of the fact, Sir, that Desker Road is a red light area. It is right in the heart of the city. Can we move these brothel houses to elsewhere?

Column: 1437



    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, it is a traditional area. People know about it. If we disperse the brothels there, it will create new problems.

Column: 1437

ENROLMENT INFORMATION ON OVERSEAS UNIVERSITIES
(Setting up of special unit)



    6. Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Minister for Education whether his Ministry has any plans to set up a special unit to (a) provide enrolment information on overseas universities to students who are unable to gain entry into the local universities and wish to pursue their education overseas; and (b) establish contacts with our overseas students, letting them know of job opportunities available at home, thereby encouraging their return.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Sir, Singapore offers students a range of higher education opportunities. About 20% of each cohort qualify to enter our two universities each year and about 40% of each cohort qualify for entry into polytechnics. And this means that about 60% of each cohort qualify for higher qualification in either our universities or polytechnics. This is one of the highest percentages in the world.

    Singaporeans may also choose to study overseas for various reasons. It would not be appropriate for the Ministry of Education to provide information on foreign universities as we are not in a position to verify or vouch for the information on these institutions. These institutions are not under our supervision. There are already many sources of information on overseas universities. It is therefore not necessary for the Ministry of Education to provide information on such universities. Those wishing to find out about foreign universities can do so at career and university exhibitions, as well as the National Library and agencies like the United States Education Information Centre, the British Council, and the Australian Education Centre.

    With regard to Singaporeans studying overseas, the eight "Contact Singapore"

Column: 1438

Centres of the Ministry of Manpower keep in touch with Singaporeans overseas, including the students studying overseas. There are also more than 70 Overseas Singapore Clubs (OSC) that are co-ordinated by the Singapore International Foundation. The "Contact Singapore" Centres provide information on what is happening in Singapore and also advice on the jobs available. Activities are also organised to raise our students' awareness of national issues and help them maintain their Singapore identity.

    One example of what Contact Singapore does is Contact Singapore runs SEARCH (or Singapore Employment Advisory and Recruitment Channel). This is a programme to help match students and professionals' skills with employers' manpower needs. SEARCH aims to reach out to students, professionals and companies by offering a variety of services, and they have their own website at http://www.contactsingapore.com.sg.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: May I ask the Minister whether the Government keeps track of the number of students who study in overseas universities, in order to know the total pool of university graduates?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not have complete information of this because Singaporeans going overseas to study are not required to register with us.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Minister whether the Ministry would be more lenient with our students who have borderline results to enter our tertiary institutions?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, wherever we draw the line, there will always be borderline cases.

INTERVIEW DOCTRINE OF POLICE OFFICERS


    7. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry will make public the doctrine for questioning of police suspects laid down for the guidance of police officers.

Column: 1439



    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the Interview Doctrine will not be made public. The Interview Doctrine is an internal confidential document to guide officers in their work within the framework of the law. It contains operational details for smooth running of police work in relation to the interviewing of persons. In particular, we cannot be `educating' the criminally-inclined to beat the system.

    Let me assure the House that the interviewing process set out in the Interview Doctrine is in accordance with the laws. This must be the case as the evidence admitted in Court by the Police must be able to stand up to scrutiny by lawyers and the Court itself.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister what good is it if the citizen himself does not know what his rights are and what is permitted in the questioning of him by the police officers? What is the good of having any doctrine locked away in the bosom of the police officers?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, not every citizen offends the law. Most of them do not. Those few who do really have reason to fear why they should be interrogated by the police. When the police interview a person they are not interested in just getting a confession from that person. They are interested in the truth, and in getting the truth, they have to make sure that they conduct their interview process in accordance with the law. If they cannot do it in accordance with the law and the case is challenged in court, then the whole case will be thrown out. So there is no reason for the police to go all out and get people who are innocent.

    What right has he got? What does he know about his rights? I think Mr Jeyaretnam himself knows that the Law Society has published a few such publications on "Police Investigation and You", "Arrest and Bail", "Proceedings in Court", "Criminal Legal Aid Scheme", and so on. And if the person is interested in finding out, read these publications.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: For the benefit of the Minister, I am aware of those publications.

Column: 1440

But my question again is this: is the Minister saying that a person arrested by the police has no right whatsoever and that the police officers can deal with him in any manner they choose?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, everyone of us has rights. Nobody can deal with anybody in any way he chooses. It must all be done within the context and confines of the law.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: What is the point of saying that everyone has rights when he is not told of his rights and that he can exercise them?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, when the police interview a person, it is all done within the context of what they are supposed to do.

which we must recognise. And to see this, we need to go back a chapter in our history. In the 60s, many newly independent countries had a sense of new found pride and nationalism.     My father never longed for what he did not have. Rather, he took great satisfaction in what he had and he treasured them and shared generously with his family. However, some fundamentals remain unchanged over these years. We are still a small country, despite the reclamation of more land. We remain a multi-racial and multi-religious society. As the population grows, we find that we are getting more crowded and getting into one another's way more often. As we look beyond our shores to expand our economy and seek regional and global markets, we have become more exposed to foreign influences, not only in terms of economics but, more importantly, the different cultures and values that such exposures brought along. In fact, nation-building, as the Prime Minister has said, which was already difficult in the 60s and 70s, has become more complex and challenging as we move into the next millennium. We have to reckon with the domestic forces at work, resolve the conflicts and overcome the constraints, at the same time, taking into account the external influences that affect our decisions and choices. One thing is certain, our job of nation-building is getting tougher.

see some parallels. First, the family is the foundation and an essential unit in nation-building. It is a reflection of the society at large. The successful formula to a happy family is love and respect among the members. There has to be a large dose of give and take, and every willingness to work together for the common good. Not all of us could achieve the same success in life, as we are all made differently. But all of us should in time achieve the same level of commitment to our society, to our country, whatever position we may be holding in life.

deserve our attention, especially in times of trouble. We may need them when our turn comes. It is only by overcoming troubles together that we can appreciate what we mean to one another. In doing so, the bonds between all of us will strengthen with time and we will be ready to face new challenges together. experience, my advice is to open your hearts and minds, and ask the fundamental questions which have been posed in Singapore 21.
