I speak Mandarin not very well perhaps, but I do speak some Mandarin in a way in which Singaporeans do, with a very unique Singapore accent.

    It is not just the accent. It is not just the chicken rice nor the laksa. But the very ideals and ethos of a Singapore that believes in meritocracy, in multi-racialism, in a clean government and efficiency are as much part and parcel of the Singapore identity, and I believe very much part and parcel of what we are, those of us who have grown up in Singapore. All this is part of the Singapore heartbeat.

    But if all this is already happening, then the question is: why the emphasis on the Singapore heartbeat and the Singapore 21 vision for the 21st century? If it exists already, then why this continued focus? For two reasons: first, we cannot take it for granted that the heartbeat will grow stronger and, in fact, globalisation could cause the heartbeat to grow weaker and not stronger. Second, there needs to be a nurturing of the heartbeat, for it is not as strong and steady now as we would like it

Column: 1512

to be. Listening to the Prime Minister this afternoon, we realise that there are still cleavages in our society that we need to work at, and that we need to build on, for, as he has said, we may be a country, but we are not yet a nation.

    In 1989 to 1990, I spent one and a half very happy years in Vancouver. It was there that I learnt how to golf and ski. The ski slopes were just 45 minutes away from my house. And during the winter and spring seasons, the first thing I would do when I woke up would be to look out of the window at the ski slopes, check out the weather and if fine, load the skis on my car, take a quick breakfast, and I would be at the ski slopes in 45 minutes. Needless to say, it is not that easy to ski in Singapore!

    In the summer in Vancouver, I went fishing, I went hiking. The mountains around Vancouver are glorious, and so are the golf courses. My husband and I seriously contemplated staying in Vancouver, and we actually went around looking for property, but eventually we came back. It was not an easy decision to come back, because life was good in Vancouver. There was not the kind of stress that there is in Singapore. So why did we return? Because it was only in Singapore that we felt that we could really contribute to society as equals, and not as second-class citizens. We felt that we were Asians and we wanted to be in Asia where the opportunities are.

    Similarly, I have relatives in Shanghai, cousins of about my age. And I often wonder whether it is merely an accident of history that I was born in Singapore with the opportunities which I have, which they do not have, for each of my three cousins spent many years in the villages, in the farms, having a very hard life working on the farms. Two of them did not have the privilege of going to the university simply because of the time in which they were born, about the same time as I was born.

    What is the difference? The difference is that I was born in Singapore, and being in Singapore, I had the opportunity to go to school, to go to the university and hence

Column: 1513

on, to do what I am doing now. And that is the reason why we came back. It is because, in Singapore, this is our home, we can contribute in this country in a way which is very difficult to do elsewhere. It is here, I think, as Mr Bernard Chen mentioned, that we have had the opportunity, and for those of us here in this House, to be educated and to do what we have done and to be where we are now.

    But although we feel this way, we cannot be sure that succeeding generations of Singaporeans will feel exactly the same. There is definitely a generational difference. For those who are highly skilled, highly mobile, the world is their oyster. Why should they return to Singapore? And that is the question that I think many young Singaporeans are asking themselves today, particularly those who have gone abroad to study. Why should they return to Singapore?

    In the S21 vision, we recognise that there will indeed be many more Singaporeans who will go abroad either to work or to study. And this is not only inevitable, in fact, it is desirable because of the fact that Singapore must internationalise in order to continue to prosper, if Singapore companies must go abroad in order to be able to expand and to compete. Therefore, the Singapore community in future will comprise not just the Singaporeans here but also the Singaporeans who are abroad. And we want the Singaporean community to be inclusive and not exclusive, to recognise that there will be many more Singaporeans who will be living and working abroad.

    But what is the difference? The difference is that in our vision, Singaporeans, no matter where they are in the world, should have an emotional rootedness to Singapore, that they consider Singapore as home, and that there is a loyalty and attachment to Singapore that will remain with them no matter how long they have lived or worked abroad, and because of this attachment, that they will want to contribute to Singapore in some tangible way. They could be working for a Singapore company overseas. They could be working for a company that is doing

Column: 1514

business in Singapore. Or they could simply be helping to promote goodwill for Singapore. Whatever it is, it is this issue of the emotional rootedness to Singapore that we are concerned about and we want to realise in the S21 Vision.

    How do we nurture the Singapore heartbeat, so that it grows strong and steady? The Singapore 21 report contains a number of recommendations such as consciously preserving landmarks and buildings that serve as emotional anchors. It talks about developing national icons. It talks about fostering a stronger sense of national identity. The PM mentioned the need to continue to build bridges among the races. What I would like to add here is that there is one more bridge that we need to consciously build, and that is the bridge between the public, private and people sectors. The title of the report is "Together, We Make The Difference". S21 is about the "we", it is about community, it is about bonding as a society. But unless we are careful, this one cleavage between the public and the people sectors in particular can hinder the achievement of the S21 Vision.

    It saddens me when I come across civil servants who consider NGOs and other groups in the people sector as an unruly, disorganised mass. Likewise, it also saddens me when I come across people in civil society who are cynical about Government initiatives and projects, who are cynical about the S21 report as yet another Government report and that it does not signal any real change. In other words, there still exists a mistrust between the public sector on the one hand and the people sector on the other. This gap needs to be bridged, and we do need a mindset change.

    The Singapore heartbeat is not about many hearts beating in dissonance, each to its own rhythm. It is not about the public sector doing its own thing; the private sector doing its own thing; the people sector doing its own thing. Rather it is about many hearts beating in resonance with one another. Each sector has its own strengths and its own weaknesses. We need to support one another,

Column: 1515

build one another up, and not criticise and tear down.

    Cannot Government replies, regardless of whether they are in the Forum page or otherwise, be polite and civil? Cannot the Government acknowledge good ideas which came from the people sector and not from themselves? And cannot the people sector forget the Catherine Lim affair, treat it as an incident of the past, and let us together begin a new page of partnership?

    I would urge the public sector as a start to give its response to the recommendations in the S21 report and to make these responses public. In fact, to go one step further, publish responses to the recommendations in the subject committee deliberations, so that all the efforts of the subject committees themselves do not just disappear into a black hole. For the people sector, I would say, be involved, be engaged in at least one activity, people sector activity, regardless of whether it is charity or it is a group such as preserving the environment.

    The essence of the Singapore heartbeat is about caring - that we care for our families, that we care for our community and that we care for our country - this island that we call our home. This caring, which is so much a part of the Singapore heartbeat, is the very essence of the vision that we hope will be realised in 21st century Singapore.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion in the name of Minister RAdm Teo Chee Hean.

    Sir, looking at the glossy cover of the book "Singapore 21, Together We Make The Difference", it reminded me of two things.

    First, the confident and somewhat smiling faces of the kids, our future, looking out of the jigsaw window of a complex and global environment, reminds

Column: 1516

me of what Senior Minister Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked some time back - whether there will still be Singapore 100 years hence. I also wondered what Senior Minister will have to say about vision Singapore 21. We know that on two occasions when Senior Minister was asked about his experience with multi-racialism and nation building, he choked, almost to tears. SM Lee's experience then must have been very heartwrenching. PM Goh has just shared his piece of mind with us and I totally share those sentiments.

    To my humble mind, what is embodied in "Singapore 21, Together We Make The Difference" speaks volumes of the same concerns PM Goh and SM Lee have for Singapore's future. Personally, I am confident that we will be able to make the difference, and make a success of what Singapore stands for, not only for those children's generation but that of their children's too, stretching more than 100 years.

    But before I sound over confident or even rhetorical, allow me to remind ourselves that all is not perfect, as things normally are. There may be many trials, and even tribulations, if we do not know how to manage the challenges that await us.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am sure Members will remember Singapore is not short of vision. Neither were we short of challenges. Remember the Battle for Merger, the fight against communism and communalism? Remember our "Survival" days? Remember The Next Lap and Vision 1999? All in all, we have shown that our vision statements were not mere dreams. We have also one by one overcome those challenges. We have been pragmatists, pragmatic idealists, if you like. But we also realise that the challenge of nation building is more than a marathon. In the words of PM Goh, unending.

    PM Goh has also sounded a note of caution, a dose of realism, in this debate. I think it is most timely.

    Do we not see the subtle hint of those possible 'blues' in the cover of the book?

Column: 1517

After all, as Minister Teo Chee Hean said in his opening remarks yesterday, I quote, "for those who think that conflict is a thing of the past, one need only to think of Kosovo .". And if I may add, the gory picture of an Indonesian Dayak (or was it a Malay?) carrying the dismembered head of a Madurese will remain vivid in our memory to remind us that the ugly head of ethnicity is still lurking around, even in these days of cyber technology and KBE.

    With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I too went through the riots of 1964 coming face to face with bloody racial violence. I was in Secondary 3 then and I will never forget those senseless scenes. It was at Victoria Street near where the Lavender MRT station now is that I saw Malays or Malay-looking youths being maimed and perhaps even killed, with bicycle chains, iron rods and acid bulbs. And at the end of that longest journey home for me to Geylang and Joo Chiat, I saw Malays hitting innocent Chinese, particularly a trishaw rider, with blood streaming down his swollen face.

    From that day onwards, for my sake and that of my children, and generations to come, I swore to do my utmost to make sure racial riots and violence do not return to Singapore.

    Nation building is never easy, especially for a state whose population is as diverse as that of Singapore. However, I believe that it is those kinds of challenges that will bond us together further, if we are united in our sense of purpose and direction.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the title "Make the Difference" also reminds me of another sense of mission, that of the Malay self-help group, MENDAKI, in fact the Malay community called "Making the Difference" (showed cover of the MENDAKI book).

    No, the Malays are not making a claim of copyright. Minister Teo Chee Hean should be reassured that they are instead most happy to share that symphony of purpose. For sure, we share a common destiny. After all, the slogan "Making the Difference" also emanates from Prime

Column: 1518

Minister Goh's National Day Rally speech earlier this decade.

    Whether the Malay community or Singapore 21, the rallying point is similar. The message is clear: Let us get our act together to make a success of our `Singapore Uno'. Together, as a more cohesive, multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious Singapore, we have to tackle the challenges of the next century and the next millennium head on.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, today, at the 2000 year old Great Wall of China, is a Millennium Countdown Clock which calls on its people to "seize the moment . build the motherland".

    I feel the same sentiment about preserving and enhancing our island state Singapore when reading the Singapore 21 book.

    Although the Singapore 21 Committee chose not to call it a blueprint, the possible `blues' notwithstanding, I agree that the ideas around the five pillars of Singapore 21 will serve as an important compass to navigate our future.

    The "broad strokes" of "every Singaporean matters, strong families, opportunities for all, the Singaporean heartbeat and active citizens" all add up to the sense of unity in diversity.

    This also reminds me of the broad strokes of calligraphy given to me by the renowned Pan Shou called: He Xie or Harmony.

    However, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, that is not to say that there are no shades of differences or problems here. For example, the debate over SAP schools, after over 10 years in existence, still lingers. So with the question of Malays in the army. Or, recently, the unhappiness felt particularly by the minorities about racial discrimination in employment.

    I have no problem with the official clarification given over such issues. I understand the need for SAP schools but feel reassured that more will be done to ensure that the SAP students are not isolated in their understanding and appreciation of the importance of multi-racialism.

Column: 1519



    Similarly with the Malays in the SAF, I welcome the statement made by DPM Dr Tony Tan reassuring us that the SAF will not allow anyone to be discriminated because of race. The NTUC resolution on May Day last week against any form of discrimination in employment is also timely.

    However, there will still be the need to continue to monitor such issues so as not to allow them to divide us Singaporeans. Even policies that impinge on multi-racialism, including those on racial integration in HDB estates, school enrolment, multi-racial representation in grassroots organisations, need regular revisits either for fine-tuning or revision so as to facilitate better cohesion in our multi-racial society.

    Finally, Sir, multi-racialism is too important a pillar for us to take for granted. It is critical that we ensure that multi-racialism prevails and be strengthened from time to time. It is an unending process. It is a heartwarming part of the Singapore heartbeat.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on the motion on the Singapore 21 Vision.

    Sir, I support the motion and feel fortunate that I have been involved in the S21 process for the last 18 months. Our last 30 years of nation building has been largely successful because of the style of governance we have had during those years, where the Government played a dominant role and many decisions being top down driven. The style of governance was necessary because of the political and social environment of those times.

    Looking ahead, the governance of Singapore is going to be much more complex than before because of a number of reasons. Firstly, we are heading towards a knowledge based economy but the complexity is not because of the content of such an economy, but rather how we must be organised to participate

Column: 1520

in it. Second, the world is becoming increasingly borderless and many of our people will be able to choose to live and work in most of the appealing parts of the world. Similarly, many foreigners will be living and working in Singapore, thus influencing the behaviour of Singaporeans. Third, our people are more educated today, well travelled and more exposed to the cultures, values and systems of other worlds. They will be able to and will want to play an increasingly important role in how the country is run. Fourth, as we progress, the needs of people become more sophisticated and as we clearly know, basic needs like food, shelter and job having been fulfilled will give way to higher level needs like self-esteem, individual rights and spirituality.

    Sir, managing the affairs of the country in the future will therefore become a more difficult job because the focus of governance will become much wider compared to the last 30 years. This is because new issues have to be addressed if we really want to make Singapore the best home for everyone.

    Our past system of relying on a few good men alone will not work well. We will need many more minds to come together to offer solutions. Our formula of over dependence on the Government was acceptable in the past because both the Government and the people were comfortable with this arrangement. Today, both the people and the Government need to accept that their roles will have to change and both must find a happy balance of the formula that will work in the future. Major mindset changes need to take place first. The Government needs to let go while Singaporeans need to take more interest to do more. This must be a joint responsibility of the public, private and the people sectors.

    Sir, my subject committee studied the issue of "Singapore as a Home" thoroughly and the reason is, as Singaporeans internationalise, there will be increasing pressures on them to make choices as to where they would live, work and raise their families. We felt that if we wanted Singaporeans to call Singapore

Column: 1521

their home, a number of conditions in our country must prevail first. The most important of these is that each Singaporean must feel that he or she has a stake in the country and as a stakeholder, there must be a sense of ownership of what goes on here. For this sense of ownership to prevail, everyone must participate in the running of the country. If every Singaporean makes it his or her responsibility to contribute constructive ideas and solutions and be willing to be accountable for the outcome, then I believe we will be successful in bringing Singapore to a higher level of progress in the future.

    Sir, I therefore feel that this sense of ownership and being a stakeholder is the most important prerequisite if we are serious about realising the Singapore 21 Vision. We, as citizens, must have a buy-in to the vision. This does not belong just to the Government, not to the public sector alone, but to all of us. If we cannot achieve this sense of ownership, then I am afraid we will fail in developing this notion of Singapore as our Best Home and we will not get closer to realising our vision.

    Sir, our subject committee, very early in the process, identified the concept of emotional rootedness, as Dr Lee Tsao Yuan mentioned earlier on, as being the most important approach of developing the type of attachment that we want for Singaporeans. Physical rootedness of being physically present in Singapore alone is not enough. No matter where one's physical location is, one's sense of belonging, emotional attachment and loyalty should be to Singapore. Emotional rootedness refers to the degree of psychological commitment to the country. A high degree of emotional rootedness suggests a passionate and intense sense of belonging, commitment and loyalty to the country.

    As Singapore globalises, a larger proportion of our talented people who are highly mobile will grow. The danger is that their physical absence from Singapore might reduce the emotional commitment to the country and may result in a higher rate of emigration. The

Column: 1522

solution therefore is to encourage a high degree of emotional rootedness so that Singapore will always have a special place in one's heart, as a home. It is only then that we can achieve the Singapore heartbeat that we have talked about.

    Sir, in developing the goal of the Singapore Heartbeat with the vision of Singapore as a Home, our committee focused on how we could strengthen the emotional rootednesss of Singaporeans and we realised that there are many factors involved in creating the sense of belonging.

    The best home must provide the best hope for its people. There must be confidence and not fear of the future. Singapore should offer a good quality of life, not just for those who we traditionally classify as being successful, but also to all citizens. No matter what one's race, religion or background is, there must be harmony, unity of purpose and a transcending sense of national identity. These common attitudes and attributes will uniquely identify the Singaporean community of the future.

    People of all races must make special efforts to learn of the beliefs and peculiarities of each other's practices and ways of life. They must make it a personal responsibility to be aware of the sensitivities and to promote a spirit of tolerance and understanding.

    Sir, in this respect, I would like to touch on a few of the recommendations that our subject committee made. Firstly, on encouraging the community spirit to blossom through more bottom-up initiatives. Sir, we have many grassroots organisations, the main ones being Government or PA-driven. They have been very successful in serving the needs of citizens, particularly those living in the HDB estates, through organisations like the Residents' Committees. The Community Development Councils are also starting to be very effective in promoting community bonding. There are also many other non-Government linked volunteer organisations like the Lions Club, the Buddhist Lodge and many others who

Column: 1523

have played a very important role in promoting community bonding. Our committee, however, felt that the participation rate of Singaporeans in such organisations and in performing community service is far too low. In fact, a survey that was conducted by the S21 Committee also showed this.

    More encouragement and latitude should be given to people wanting to organise themselves in community service activities. We hope to see more community activities and civic organisations through bottom-up initiatives with people with a common interest getting together spontaneously, rather than being asked to do so. These will complement the many existing organisations that we already have. These organisations should not be Government-driven and the people sector must take the responsibility for forming such organisations to improve the lives of Singaporeans.

    Secondly, everyone is important and we must broaden the definition of meritocracy and success. Sir, the practice of meritocracy has served us well in the past. It has enabled the best and the brightest to rise through the system, irregardless of race, family backdrop or gender. However, the system may no longer work as we move towards a different type of environment where being academically smart alone is not enough. Sir, for us to succeed in the future, we feel that the current definition of meritocracy is too narrow, focusing only on academic and economic excellence. This definition and the practice of meritocracy and the way we define success along the same lines does not allow every Singaporean to develop to his or her full potential. If we look back in history, the best leaders in the world are not all scholars. On the contrary, many did not have straight `As' or impressive paper qualification. A true leader possesses many qualities consisting of both IQ and EQ factors and I feel that it is about time we modified our practice of meritocracy to include the new EQ measures, which I can agree, are difficult to measure. But this needs to be done. Our current scholar

Column: 1524

system which was set in place many years ago needs to change so that we will be able to select leaders of diverse backgrounds and not those of the same mould to lead the country. We have to move away from stereotype role models and include both non-scholars as well as those who have talents other than being able to score well in examinations as examples of successful Singaporeans whom we value.

    Sir, every Singaporean has a role to play and as long as everyone tries to achieve his or her full potential, we should be proud of them. Not everyone will make it to the top, neither can such a society exist because we need people at all levels of society for a country to function. We therefore should respect and give equal opportunities to everyone no matter what they do for a living. It is about time that we practised meritocracy with a heart, appreciating and recognising that every Singaporean is important and must feel as such.

    Sir, the third issue that I would like to talk about is one of racial harmony and the Prime Minister has touched about this earlier on. I would like to share with the House some of the issues that came about as we went through our process of getting feedback from the various focus groups. In the early stages of our discussion, I sensed a more in-depth study was needed on this issue, especially from the perspectives of the minority communities. I therefore decided to conduct further focus group discussions with the minority communities. I had a total of three such discussions and I would like to share the findings with this House. And I also feel that we need to discuss these openly and address them if we truly want to achieve excellence in the area of racial harmony. While legislation has been used as one tool to ensure racial harmony in Singapore, I feel that we need to go beyond rules and regulations to ensure that all races interact and live happily with each other so that our fundamentals of a multi-racial and multi-religious society will continue to exist for a long time to come.

    Sir, from the minorities' point of view, there are a number of issues. First of all,

Column: 1525

awareness and sensitivity. If each one of us does not make a special effort to know the sensitivities and peculiarities of each other's way of life, the danger is that we may end up offending others without realising that we have done so. In this respect, there is fear among the minority communities that I spoke to that this lack of awareness is starting to emerge in our society. For example, one issue raised is that while most members of the minority communities understood the need of the Speak Mandarin Campaign, some felt that it is inappropriate for the members of the Chinese community to break into speaking Mandarin when people of other races who do not understand Mandarin are present in group discussions or in a meeting. Many have felt offended, but are not expressing this concern openly. Similarly, not knowing that Muslim's food preference has to be halal could result in a big problem. Sir, a parliamentary colleague of mine thought that I am Tamil speaking. I did not feel offended, but rather amused at the lack of awareness and understanding of who I am after so many years of multi-racial society. If this trend continues, we may see an erosion of the values that we have put in place for a multi-racial society and this needs to be addressed.

    The second issue that came out during the discussion with the minority communities was the SAP school that has been much debated before. The issue is not that the minority communities do not support the concept of SAP school. But the worry is that the future leaders of our country would have gone through a system of education without having much interaction with people of the non-Chinese race. These same people would then be responsible for making policies that affect other races. How can they be conversant of the sensitivities of each of the minority races if they never had a real experience of mixing with them?

    The issue is not whether SAP schools are necessary. But with SAP schools present, how can we resolve this issue of not being aware and hence potentially making mistakes affecting sensitive racial issues in the future? Our subject committee recommends that the twinning of

Column: 1526

SAP and non-SAP schools be done as a solution. Perhaps, all ECAs should be done at a twinning level if we want to ensure true interaction. Substantial interaction needs to happen throughout the year if we want to make a real difference. Doing it once or twice a year during multi-racial day is not enough.

    Sir, the third issue that came up was the effect of the ethnic based self-help groups. Whilst the objectives are good, they have resulted in less help across ethnic and racial lines. In fact, the current practice creates a real danger of the various races being alienated from one another. Sir, I feel that when I grew up, there was much more inter-racial interaction and we did not highlight the differences among the various races and therefore our inter-racial bonding was strengthened. Today, our children are growing up with a greater awareness of the differences because of the way we organise, either in schools, for example, in SAP schools or in certain schools where students studying the same mother tongue are put in the same class, or through the various self-help groups. Our subject committee has suggested that we promote more inter-racial interaction by having an umbrella body for all self-help groups, so that the various races can contribute towards each other's efforts. We all need to think and see ourselves as Singaporeans first.

    The fourth issue that came out is the practice of meritocracy. One unintended impact of our practice of meritocracy, which I must admit, is a transparent system and applies equally to all races. It is because the members of the minority races, the Malays, Indians and Eurasians, do not perform as well as the Chinese in the academic measures of examinations, they end up not being selected as scholars or to key positions in Government, because of the way we practise meritocracy by academic excellence alone. While the long-term solution has been correctly identified as one of uplifting the academic performances of the minority races, which the self-help groups are trying to do, I believe if we can change the way we measure success and practise meritocracy to include non-academic

Column: 1527

measures, this unintended effect can be easily resolved.

    The next issue that I want to discuss, and this affects not only the minority communities, was brought up during our other focus group discussions, and that is our education system. Many Members have spoken about the competitive and stressful education system. That, I must agree, has served us well in the past. Our system of education, however, needs to be fine-tuned to remove those elements that are not tolerant to failures and are not forgiving to those who are late developers. I am referring to the early streaming in our schools and the subsequent streaming throughout the system which I feel will result in a class society in Singapore in the long-term, if we are not careful.

    While the intent of streaming was to segregate students into various capability levels and let each group develop at its own pace, I feel that in implementing, the educators, the parents and the society have created a system where emphasis is placed on making the good better, and with the best resources being used so that they will continue to improve and score well and the school's performance will improve. We treat those who are streamed into EM3 and into the Normal (Technical) stream as failures too early in the lives of our children. In my opinion, we have yet to see this class society developing in Singapore because this will only happen when the children who went through this system become parents and have children of their own. And I see real danger of this happening in the future if we do not put in efforts to change the system that we have.

    I would like to share with the House two real examples that I came across. One was during the focus group discussion that I had with one of the minority groups. A young man aged mid-30s, told me that he was streamed into EM3, and then into Normal (Technical) stream and he later went to ITE. He told me that he felt very frustrated that he was treated as a failure

Column: 1528

and as an outcast and he felt very angry with the system. He even contemplated suicide at one stage of his life. Because of his frustration, he felt that he had no place in the system in Singapore. However, fortunately, he self-motivated himself and wanted to prove to everyone that he is not a failure, and that the system was wrong in classifying him as one. Today, he holds a Masters degree and he is doing well in life. He is still bitter with the education system and fears for his children if they have to go through what he went through.

    In another incident, during one of my meet-the-people sessions, the parents of a 9-year old boy came to see me and they sought my help to appeal for their son to be transferred from EM3 to EM2 stream, and pleaded with me that if their son remained in the EM3 stream, his life would be destroyed forever. And they made this comment in front of the child. Our system is not forgiving and every one is responsible for this, including our educators, parents and society.

    The issue of self-esteem is also a serious one and I have seen this in the faces of those who came from the lower streams. I would like to refer the House to an article which appeared in the Straits Times on 12 July 1998 regarding the Gifted Programme. It reads, "Being Gifted is fine, but what if you are Normal." This article was written by a 20-year old undergraduate who was selected for the Gifted Programme in 1998. Let me quote from the article to illustrate my point on our education system:

    "Recently, a friend of mine who taught both the GEP [which is a gifted programme] and the non-GEP students as a relief teacher told me she thought that they were quite different when it came to self-esteem. The GEP students were much more self-assured and spoke up more often in class. Girls in the normal stream were vocal, rowdy but have little self-esteem. However, we want to say it is not true that the practice of streaming and its effect of slapping labels onto students does draw invisible lines that shape our self-confidence or the lack of it."

    As we segregate our children in the various streams, they miss out on the opportunity to learn from one another. Putting all the slow learners together is a self-defeating approach. Let me quote from the article again:

Column: 1529



    "As far as I know, there is not much interaction among the different streams. It is almost an "us against them" sort of mentality sometimes."

Hopefully, allowing the students to work together will let them understand that they are alike in many ways. And this was after this writer made a recommendation that they should be spending a lot more time together rather than separate from one another.

    I would also like to highlight that coming from a person who went through the system, and who went through the better part of the system and feels this way about it, speaks volumes about the need to change. Let me quote the writer again:

    "But the weeding out procedure of our education system which may be the most efficient is not entirely perfect since it is difficult to measure the potential of an individual. Slow starters or those who do not qualify as gifted in Primary 3 or 6 miss a precious opportunity."

    This is the reality of our education system and of how all of us, the schools, the parents and society are treating those who are not academically well-off and late developers. We have to change if we are serious about the notion of "Every Singaporean matters". I am hopeful that the Ministry of Education will look into these issues when they implement the "mass customisation" approach to our education system, which the Minister for Education spoke about during the Budget debate this year.

    In conclusion, I would like to add that we have set the stage for changes in the way Singapore should be governed in the future. Many recommendations we have made will require mindset changes among all sectors of society. We must ensure that every one feels they have a useful role to play in the development of Singapore and that they are valued as individuals and as a community. While our past approaches of nation-building have worked, the same approaches cannot ensure continued success in the future. Ultimately, we must all adopt a sense of responsibility and ownership to want to make a difference and the key ingredient that will make this work is the trust that the people, public and the private sectors

Column: 1530

have in each other. I am confident that we will make the necessary changes because I see a determined PAP leadership who wants to make these changes and who is sincere in sharing this vision that we have defined as a nation.

    I am grateful for being given an opportunity to be involved in the S21 process and in helping to define the S21 Vision. I believe that the people are wholeheartedly behind this Vision. The 6,000 or so people we consulted, each represents many more Singaporeans because we consulted leaders from various sectors of society, and together, I strongly believe we have reached out to a significant proportion of Singaporeans in arriving at our Vision.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion standing in the name of the Minister for Education.

    The report by the Singapore 21 Committee could not have been more timely. As we prepare to face the next millennium, it is right that we should collectively, as a nation, take a step backwards and define what we want for the country in the years ahead. Although Singapore has a relatively short history, we are, nevertheless, a country with our own identity, and well on our way to becoming a nation that all of us, whether we be Indians, Chinese or others, can be proud of.

    In the last 30 years, we as a people have gone through many milestones in our collective memory. We can think of us struggling for independence or fighting with the communists, or overcoming the evils of communalism, or struggling with calamities and disasters, such as the Hotel New World collapse, and, most recently, the SilkAir crash of MI185. Whatever these events, we cannot deny that the common experience has got the people closer together, either in common suffering or in common celebration.

    Our achievements in the last 30 years have made Singaporeans extremely

Column: 1531

proud of themselves. A pride that sometimes bordered on arrogance and is seen as such by many outsiders. While arrogance is not an attitude we want to encourage of our people, it nonetheless reflects the pride which our people have for this country. Taken in the right spirit, it is an attitude we want to preserve and build upon so that our foundation as a nation becomes stronger with the passing years.

    The vision statement of the Singapore 21 Committee, in all its component parts, must surely lead to the question of strengthening the country as a nation; a nation with an identity that over time would become strong with a heart beating strongly for it. How do we ensure that? How will opportunities be perceived? The Committee has, among other things, argued quite rightly that the Singapore of the 21st century must provide every opportunity for Singaporeans to pursue their personal rainbows, whether it be the arts, sports, entertainment or other areas. Singapore of the future must continue to be a place where opportunities abound and where we can find here, the same optimism as our forefathers did.

    In seeking to provide these opportunities, one argument is that we must practise an open door to encourage talented foreigners to come. By bringing in talented foreigners, they will be able to contribute to our continued growth and prosperity, and in the process, help create a thriving city which provides opportunities for all. The logic behind the argument of foreign talent is hard to fault. I am, for one, all in support of us bringing in foreign talent if, in the process, these foreigners can work towards the fulfilment of the Singapore dream. However, while most discussions in recent months centred around the principle of bringing in foreign talent to Singapore, little has been said of the question of who is a foreign talent, and how can foreign talents be introduced to this country without unduly upsetting the present social balance.

    Indeed, nobody denies that foreign talents can make a positive contribution to

Column: 1532

the Singapore economy. If a Nobel prize laureate were to set up home in Singapore, he would indeed qualify as a foreign talent. Alternatively, if Bill Gates decides to migrate to Singapore, he too would qualify as a foreign talent. Realistically, it is unlikely that Singapore would be attractive enough for such people. For them, they are successful and there are very few reasons why they want to pull themselves out and relocate to Singapore.

    If we are not talking about people in this class, one would suppose that we are talking about those who are good in their respective fields but who are not necessarily in the top band. Nonetheless, these people may have the skills and expertise to make a contribution to Singapore. If, by definition, foreign talent refers to these people, the question that many Singaporeans have asked is, how can we identify these people as the kind of people with the talents we want. In its common usage in recent months, foreign talent has come to be loosely treated as being synonymous with those who have studied at some respected universities overseas and may have, perhaps, acquired some working experience which may be of relevance to Singapore. Possibly, some of these people may have also acquired some proven track record as well. And so it is that over time we have welcomed into our country many of these people from China and India and elsewhere who possess these qualifications.

    Sir, as I have said, I have no objection to foreign talents coming to Singapore to make a contribution. However, one must be very careful in the way in which we collectively understand what foreign talent means. If foreign talent merely means taking on board someone with a post-graduate degree, with some relevant working experience in some ritzy merchant banking house or manufacturing concern, I am not sure if these people would qualify as true talents who can make a positive contribution to our country.

    The issue, as some Singaporeans have seen it, is one of acquiring the relevant experience and expertise that Singapore

Column: 1533

needs to propel the country into the 21st century. If to acquire the experience and expertise would mean going overseas to study and gaining the necessary working experience before returning home as a talent, then we may be sending a different message to our people that it is not good enough to go to our local universities and start their working career here. This could well be an unintended effect of what we want to achieve in the long run, and would put the local graduates in a disadvantaged position, vis-a-vis those who went overseas to study and to work. The irony deepens even further if as a result of his inability to qualify for a university in Singapore, the person chooses to study overseas and make a success of it, acquires the relevant experience and comes back as a talent. We may well ask how different is this person from the local boy who spends his time faithfully in Singapore. Unless we have a proper yardstick to define who a foreign talent is, we may all be deceiving ourselves if we merely employed someone with some qualification and treat him as a talent when our own people can do the job just as well.

    Sir, if we are not able to carefully sift between the foreign talent and those who merely want to come here to seek out opportunities for work, we may sadly end up in a situation where Singaporeans may find themselves out of a job simply because foreigners have displaced them by having the right assets, even if they may not be true talents.

    On foreign talents, most Singaporeans would readily accept the position if a foreign CEO was brought in to run a local company. However, one must realise that a foreign CEO who is asked to take charge of a company must have capable officers to help him fulfil his mandate. A foreign CEO, who is brought in to run an organisation, would more likely than not be forced to replace the middle management with his own appointees as well, since he needs to perform to prove his worth to the organisation. The CEO's appointees may not necessarily be local employees. In fact, they will, in all likelihood, be foreigners whom he is familiar with.

Column: 1534

These managers who come in would equally be encouraged to find their own team members who can help them achieve their mandate. And so the displacement may just go down the corporate chain. The question is, how can we ensure that in the process of seeking these foreign talents to create opportunities for us, we, by our own actions, are not unwittingly displacing Singaporeans who are equally able and capable of doing these jobs? In trying to create a vision where we provide opportunities for all, the Government must be clear as to who these foreign talents are, the type of opportunities these foreign talents can create for Singaporeans and the assurance that these are true opportunities and not lost opportunities.

    For us in Singapore, it is very important that the perception of opportunities remains among Singaporeans. Singapore should be a place where opportunities continue to abound. Otherwise, it would be very difficult indeed to maintain the strong heartbeat for Singapore that we want all Singaporeans to have.

    Home is where the heart is, and home is also where opportunities are made available. Where the members feel they do not belong, it is no longer home, and where there is no home, there is no heartbeat.

    Many of us speak passionately about Singapore and its future. I can understand this as Singapore is the only home we know. Like it or not, our destinies as a people are tied together. We have to make a success of this nation. There is no alternative. I agree with the call of the Government that we must continue to keep the heart beating strongly for Singapore. As our people go overseas to work or to study or even migrate, the diaspora of Singaporeans around the world does not matter for us as long as wherever they are, whatever they do, these people can continue to know and remember their place of origin.

    Turtles go to the beaches of Trengganu, I am told, to lay eggs once a year. And after the eggs are hatched, they will

Column: 1535

scramble to the sea and travel all over the world. But wherever they are, the turtles always know their place of origin and will make the journey back faithfully to lay their eggs, to perpetuate themselves for posterity. Equally, the Jews and the Chinese are spread all over the world. They will always have a deep remembrance of their place of origin. It is this association and connection with their place of origin that has built up the bonds and the ties that will hold the people together in a crisis.

    We want Singaporeans to develop a stronger sense of belonging and commitment to this country, whether they live in Singapore or overseas. We must embrace this common vision of what this country stands for, what its values are and whether it is worth returning if one needs to. At the end of the day, there must be a conviction that this country is a country worth fighting and dying for.

    I agree that all of us can actually play a part in shaping this country. The more successful Singaporeans must carry the additional duty for other Singaporeans to help them embrace this common vision. This vision of Singapore as a place we call home.

    Sir, I was at a constituency dinner recently. The function was organised for the purpose of bringing together senior citizens from old folks homes to Tampines Central for dinner. And I can assure Members of this House that we did not charge them $300 for coming to Tampines. Anyway, the elderly citizens who are residents of these homes are there because they have no one to turn to. They are essentially abandoned by their children. Although they are abandoned by their children, there was no lack of love that was shown for them by the many volunteers who were there to help. I could see how these residents tenderly looked after and gently escorted the old folks whenever they needed to leave the table. These are all volunteers who give their time freely for community service. And it is impressions like these that essentially

Column: 1536

warm my heart and make me realise the true meaning of calling Singapore home, a place where we all feel as one big family in this country.

    For Singaporeans living overseas, we must endeavour to keep the heart beating beyond the first generation. Singapore, unfortunately, does not have a history long and deep enough for it to have a cultural DNA that Singaporeans, no matter where they are, can pass from one generation to another.

    Beyond the first generation of living overseas, children born of Singaporean parents would no longer have any attachment to Singapore unless they spend some time at home. If we are prepared to accept a diaspora of Singaporeans, then I would encourage and urge our Government to give some attention to see how we can keep this heartbeat going for Singaporeans overseas.

    Sir, our gathering here today marks a milestone in our national history which signifies renewal as well as change. We alone hold in our mortal hands the power to abolish all forms of ill-will and distrust among fellow Singaporeans, and all manner of differences in the name of a much better future we want to create for ourselves and our children. These commitments spring forth from the beliefs for which our forebears fought so hard to establish. We dare not forget today that we are heirs of the first revolution. The revolution brought on by our pioneers has given us life in Singapore as we know it. Let us go forth from this time and place to tell our friends and our foes alike that we intend to keep the heart beating strongly for Singapore and for many more generations of Singaporeans to come. Let every nation know whether they wish us well or ill that we shall pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend, oppose any foe, to assure the survival and success of Singapore. This much, we must pledge.
